etymologies: mid 16th century; earliest use found in Glasse of Truthe. From classical Latin subreptīcius (also surreptīcius; in post-classical Latin also subreptitius, surreptitius) stolen, kidnapped, in post-classical Latin also false, deceitful, taking place by stealth + -ous

definitions: Obtained by subreption; involving or characterized by the suppression of truth or the concealment of facts.
